summary: This document is a February 7, 2019 letter from Professor Paul G. Cassell to the Director of the DOJ Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR), requesting an investigation into alleged professional misconduct by DOJ attorneys in the non-prosecution of Jeffrey Epstein. It includes a 2010 letter from Cassell to U.S. Attorney Wifredo A. Ferrer detailing specific allegations of irregularities in the Epstein case, and a 2011 OPR response declining to investigate due to ongoing litigation.

persons.name: Paul G. Cassell
persons.role: Criminal Law Professor, Former Federal Judge, Attorney for Victims
persons.context: Author of the letters; a former Associate Deputy Attorney General, Assistant U.S. Attorney, and federal judge who is requesting an investigation into the handling of the Jeffrey Epstein prosecution and representing several of Epstein's victims.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central subject of the alleged misconduct; a billionaire accused of sexually abusing dozens of minor girls, who received a non-prosecution agreement from federal prosecutors.

persons.name: Ben Sasse
persons.context: Mentioned as the senator who requested the OPR investigation that prompted Cassell's 2019 letter.

persons.name: Wifredo A. Ferrer
persons.role: United States Attorney for the Southern District of Florida
persons.context: The recipient of Cassell's 2010 letter, who was asked to investigate potential improper influences in his office's handling of the Epstein case.

persons.name: Ken Starr
persons.context: Identified as one of Epstein's 'most high-powered attorneys'; his correspondence with the U.S. Attorney's office was allegedly withheld during discovery.

persons.name: Lilly Ann Sanchez
persons.context: Identified as one of Epstein's 'most high-powered attorneys'; her correspondence with the U.S. Attorney's office was allegedly withheld during discovery.

persons.name: Robert Roxburgh
persons.context: Named as an Epstein employee (pilot) who was represented by the former prosecutor after he left the U.S. Attorney's office.

connections.description: Starr is identified as one of Epstein's most high-powered attorneys involved in plea negotiations.
Sanchez is identified as one of Epstein's most high-powered attorneys involved in plea negotiations.
Roxburgh is identified as a pilot employed by Epstein.
Cassell is an attorney representing victims of Epstein and is formally requesting investigations into Epstein's prosecution.

events.title: FBI Investigation Opened
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida and the FBI opened a criminal investigation into allegations Jeffrey Epstein sexually abused dozens of minor girls.

events.title: Signing of Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA)
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office entered into a binding non-prosecution agreement with Jeffrey Epstein, blocking federal prosecution for sex offenses and limiting him to 18 months in state jail.

events.title: Cassell's Initial Allegation Letter
events.description: Paul Cassell wrote to U.S. Attorney Wifredo Ferrer requesting an investigation into potential improper influences in the Epstein prosecution.

events.title: OPR Declines to Investigate
events.description: The DOJ Office of Professional Responsibility responded to Cassell, stating they would not investigate the allegations because they were subject to ongoing litigation.

events.title: Cassell's Renewed Request to OPR
events.description: Following Senator Sasse's request, Cassell wrote to the OPR Director renewing his request for an investigation into the Epstein prosecution.

locations: Salt Lake City, Utah (S.J. Quinney College of Law)
keyFacts: Professor Paul Cassell, a former federal judge, alleges 'the most suspicious criminal case' he has ever encountered regarding the non-prosecution of Jeffrey Epstein.

Cassell's 2010 letter details four specific areas of suspicion: 1) Epstein may have been tipped off before a search warrant was executed, 2) a senior prosecutor left the U.S. Attorney's office and then represented Epstein's associates, 3) Epstein withheld correspondence from powerful attorneys (Ken Starr, Lilly Ann Sanchez) during discovery, and 4) the FBI may have been kept in the dark about the non-prosecution agreement.
The DOJ Office of Professional Responsibility declined to investigate in 2011, citing ongoing litigation under the Crime Victims' Rights Act.
The letter references a federal investigation with evidence from over 30 minor girls alleging sexual offenses by Epstein.
Cassell represents several of Epstein's victims, referred to as Jane Doe 1, Jane Doe 2, Jane Doe 3, and Jane Doe 4.
